title: Will Bayley blasts Strictly judge Craig's 'stiff' criticism
text:

Will Bayley has hit out at judge Craig Revel Horwood's criticism that he was "too stiff", retorting that he "has no ankles.

Paralympian Will was in tears earlier today after saying that he was "gutted" to be quitting the show during his appearance on It Takes Two.

Will, 31, was told that his freak knee injury could take six months to heal, meaning that he wouldn't be able to return to the programme.

While he was competing, Craig criticised Will for being too rigid and that he needed to up his game.

(Image: BBC/Guy Levy)

(Image: SOPA Images/LightRocket via Gett)

The sportsman, who suffers with arthrogyposis in all four of his limbs, told The Sun: "Craig said things to me like I should be improving, and I should have, but he also said I was too stiff.

“I mean I have no idea how I’m supposed to do that — I don’t have any ankles, so obviously I can’t do rise and fall.”

However Will has also insisted that he was glad he didn't receive special treatment and that he was treated like everyone else.

But he added: "They said some really positive comments, but they weren’t scared to criticise me. I was thinking sometimes with the stiff comments, I have no idea how I can do that.

(Image: BBC)

"But Craig is harsh with everyone, and I didn’t want them to feel sorry for me and think ‘Oh we’ll give him a ten’."

Earlier today, Will was comforted by professional Janette Manrara as he said he "didn't want it to end like this".

He also insisted that his injury was not due to his disability and that he didn't want people to be put off dancing.

Speaking to host Zoe Ball, he said that he was "shocked" about the outcome and was incredibly emotional after watching their time on the show in a VT.

(Image: BBC)

He said: "It's really gutting isn't it? Because I didn't want it to end like this."

He added: "There were so many positive things as well... some of the lifts were amazing and I didn't think I'd be able to do this."

"I was scared of embarrassing myself and she believed in me," Will said, beginning to get choked up. "I just wanted to help people."

Zoe and Janette insisted that he did as he broke down in tears, prompting the pro dancer to grab a tissue and wipe away his tears.

(Image: BBC)

(Image: BBC)

"[My injury] is not because of my disability," he insisted emotionally. "I don't want people to be put off dancing."

Speaking to Will at the end of the interview. Janette said: "Thank you for trusting me, thank you for being one of the best best partners on the show."

And viewers were heartbroken too, flocking to Twitter to comment.

One wrote: "I am in tears watching you say goodbye #ItTakesTwo. You are so inspirational and have done an amazing job . You should both be very proud of yourself and Janette."

While another commented: "What an absolute legend @WillBayleytt is, absolutely gutted to see him & @JManrara so upset on #ItTakesTwo! @bbcstrictly."

A third remarked: "Oh god I’m so emo @WillBayleytt @JManrara @ZoeTheBall that was heartbreaking #ItTakesTwo."

"Oh god I'm in bits watching Will & Janette's interview on #ItTakesTwo What a wonderful inspiration Will is," another tweeted.

The pair were given a bye to next week, but his injury has failed to heal and forced him to pull out of the competition.

This means that there will be just three contestants in the final this year rather than the usual four.

(Image: BBC)

(Image: BBC/Guy Levy)

The gold-medal winning Paralympian said he was devastated to leave the series – which had been one of the highlights of his life.

The table-tennis champ, who suffers with arthrogyposis in all four of his limbs, said: “I’m gutted my Strictly journey has had to come to an end. I’ve loved being part of the show, and am so grateful for the phenomenal support we have received.

"I want to say a special thank you to Janette for believing in me, and giving me the confidence to believe in myself.

"The things we achieved, from our couple’s choice dance, through to the lifts in our salsa, will stay with me forever. I’ve had the time of my life.”

(Image: DIGITAL/EROTEME.CO.UK)

His scans have shown that his injury, which was obtained during rehearsals for the jive, may take up to six months for his injury to heal.

The first celebrity forced to pull out of the competition was Made in Chelsea star Jamie Laing, who injured himself before the competition even began.

Jamie landed awkwardly during the red carpet launch, consequently hurting his leg.

He was replaced by Emmerdale star Kelvin Fletcher, who was paired with Oti Mabuse and looks set to make it through to the latest stages of the contest.

Strictly Come Dancing ’s executive producer Sarah James said: “We are so sad that Will is unable to continue on the show. He is an incredible and talented person who has brought us some unforgettable moments this series - in particular his powerful and moving couples choice routine.

"He will be greatly missed and we wish him a speedy recovery.”

*Strictly Come Dancing returns next Saturday at 7pm on BBC One
description: Paralympian Will had to quit the show after he was told his 'freak' knee injury could take six months to heal
